results.title: Asian highway
results.creator_credit: Shizuo Kimura, Akira Taketomi, Ivan Chapman, Japan Broadcasting Corporation and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description: The story of the transformation of the world’s oldest road into a modern all-weather motor highway. The ancient caravan route stretches 8,000 miles across Asia from the Iranian-Turkish border to East Pakistan. Work started in 1958 and when completed modern asphalt or concrete roads will stretch almost halfway across Asia, linking up with European highway networks. It will serve an area where more than 600 million people live. Shows the people who live along the highway, their way of life, and their emergence from seclusion.

results.title: Asian earth
results.brief_description: Documents the activities and provlems of a Hindu peasant family of the lower Ganges Valley. They are seen at work, play, and worship during the cycle of one year. In the narration, the mother of the family presents here explanation and interpretation. (Awards: First prize at Golden Reel Festival; Cleveland; Stamford; Illinois)

results.title: Asian crescent
results.creator_credit: Peter Hopkinson, James Carr and Lever Brothers
results.brief_description: A look at some of the social and economic problems facing the Malaysian Federation. Although born in Malaysia the people may be Chinese, Indian, Malay, with different languages, religions and ways of life. The federation is determined to give equality of opportunity and a real sense of natural unity to all its people.

results.title: Asian artists in crystals
results.brief_description: Describes an exhibit of American crystalware engraved with designs created by sixteen artists representing Burma, Ceylon, China, Egypt, India, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Japan, Korea, Pakistan, the Philippines, Syria, Thailand, Turkey, and Vietnam. Shows the work of these artists, how American designers captured the mood of the drawings in crystal form, and how American craftsmen translated the drawings into engravings.

results.title: Asian adventure
results.creator_credit: Greg Grainger, Australian Television Network and Grainger Maynard
results.brief_description: This visually stunning documentary captures the most forbidding and exotic of Asian locations in a series of fast moving adventures. Journey through China on a month-long bicycle tour through the southern Province of Guandong, witness dragon-boat racing and the magic of Chinese National Day celebrations. In India visit the magnificent waterways and colourful houseboats of Kashmir, tour the ancient fort city of Jhodpur and travel by camel across the Great Rajasthan Desert. Witness the magnificent spectacle of the city of Jaisalmer and embark on a fascinating bike ride from the famous pink city of Jaipur to Agra and it’s breathtaking temple of love, the Taj Mahal.

results.title: Asia: two thirds and counting
results.creator_credit: Edward Magruder Jones and United Nations Films
results.brief_description: Asia now has almost two-thirds of the world’s people and may double its total by the year 2000. India, China and Japan have approached the problem of overpopulation in three different ways, eg India initially tried massive birth control, but is now attacking poverty as the main source of its problems. China has always done this, with success. Japan now has little increase, but faces other problems. The approach of each country is examined and the long-term effects of the action taken are discussed.

results.title: Asia: physical geography
results.brief_description: Asia is the largest of earth’s seven continents. Extending over 44 million square kilometres, it dominates the landmass it shares with Europe. Of the world’s four oceans, three - the Arctic, the Pacific and the Indian - border Asia, while the fourth - the Atlantic - is connected to it by the Mediterranean Sea. This video takes viewers on a journey from the deserts that sweep through southwest Asia, across the center of the continent to the mountain chains that dominate central and southern Asia, from the frozen tundra north of the Arctic circle south through the taiga, the largest expanse of coniferous forest in the world, onto the grasslands of central Asia. Also examines the peninsulas and islands of monsoonal southeast Asia. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s Guide included.

results.title: Asia: a continental overview
results.brief_description: Examines the principle physical regions of Asia in terms of natural resources and human use. Gives a picture of the wide range of living conditions on this largest and most populous of the continents and emphasizes the many changes taking place in centuries-old patterns of life. No other credits available.

results.title: Asia Wise (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: John Honey, Education Dept Tasmania, Asian Studies Council and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: A compilation of some of the most important and informative reports from the ABC TV program Asia Wise during 1989. The stories address social, political and cultural issues. In the diverse and complex countries of Asia today it seems the only unifying forces are, paradoxically, change and tradition. Topics covered are: - Student protests in China; peasants in China; the new Cambodia; Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong; Japanese youth; the depletion of Asian forests; Japanese tea ceremony; Yum cha.

results.title: Asia Wise
results.creator_credit: John Honey, Education Dept Tasmania, Asian Studies Council and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: In the diverse and complex countries of Asia today, it seems that the only unifying forces are both change and tradition. This video covers: Student protests in China; peasants in modern China; the new Cambodia; Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong; Japanese youth - an education for life and breaking the pattern of tradition; the depletion of Asian forest resources; Sado - the Japanese tea ceremony; Yum Cha - traditional Chinese tea and snacks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Honey, Education Dept Tasmania, Asian Studies Council and ABC-TV (Australia)
